context: Their mostly clueless, "let's try this and see what happens" then make up a story to explain it. So many totally wrong hypotheses out there that are accepted as gospel. We are truly monkeys playing with things we don't even understand enough about to realize we're lost. In 100 years we might realize how ignorant we really are.

replies.context:
So what do you propose? Just sitting and doing nothing to learn more? Science has ALWAYS evolved as we learn more. Experimenting, theorizing and testing is part of the scientific method. And yes, theories change as we learn. That's what theories are for.
 And, yes, today we realize how ignorant we were 100 years ago too. Any generation can look 100 years into their past and marvel at how little they knew then.
The true monkey here is the one that cannot spell they're!

All true. But it's how we learn things. You're literally describing the process of discovery. Yes, we're going to get results we don't understand. We're likely to be wrong in our conclusions at first.

But then more experiments will be done. More observations will be made. New data will be combined with old data and we'll say, "Hmm. Maybe it makes more sense that ... ".

I think what you're reacting to is the arrogance perceived by the public to exist among research scientists. Well ... I agree. They can be arrogant. And narrow minded. And are often so consumed with Cognitive Dissonance and Confirmation Bias that they can't see the truth when it slaps them in the face. And though I think it is often subconscious, they are often terrified to go against the current thinking and so make conclusions based more on politics or convention than on the actual evidence.

But none of that is a reason to stop doing the experiments. Quite the opposite really. The only way to overcome the biases is data, data, and more data. The only hope we have of purging the influence of convention and politics from science is to have enough data to prove the truth beyond any human ability to ignore. And that, my friend, will take an awful lot of data.

replies.context: Do you have a basic understanding of "electricity"?  A Watt of electricity is a measure of power, not energy.  A 60-watt incandescent light bulb is powered by 60 watts of electrical energy but only gives me less than a watt of lumens in light energy I use in that hour.  I am charged by the number light-hours I use, a measure of energy and not power.  I pay about 9 cents per watt-hour of energy I use in my house.  That means I pay 9 x 60 cents, 59 cents, for every hour I have that 60-watt light bulb lit.

You pay 9 cents per kilowatt hour. You can run ten 100 watt light bulbs for one hour and it will cost you 9 cents or you can run one 1000 watt bulb for one hour and it will cost you 9 cents. Your the one that don't seem to have a grasp of basic electricity.
Do you have a basic understanding of satire? BTW: It uses 600 GWh per year, which could also power 450,000,000 homes. Africa might appreciate that. But, it's for science, so it's okay. Right?

I will simply say that a watt (named after James Watt of steam engine fame) is a unit of power, not energy.  My electric bill has many charges, mostly taxes and distribution costs.  Part of this bill is the actual electric ENERGY I used.  I pay 9 cents per kilowatt-hour.

context:
A trillion electronvolts is about the kinetic energy of a flying mosquito.
So 13.6 TeV is not really that impressive.

replies.context: Yes it is.  If you accelerated an entire mosquito to that velocity, it would have more kinetic energy than every automobile in the entire world.
if you accelerated two ants to that speed and they collided, would they be atom ants?
I am going to convert 13.6 TeV to BTUs.  You are correct that it is a measure of energy and not voltage or power.

Actually it is impressive when one considers that this is the energy being imparted on a single subatomic particle like the electron or the much more massive proton.  13.6 TeV of kinetic energy is over 0.2 BTUs.

It is that impressive when you realize a proton is about 10^24 times lighter than a mosquito. It only takes basic high school physics (p=mv) to show that the proton moves unbelievably faster than a mosquito with the same energy. Sure in reality the calculations get a bit trickier because of relativistic effects from being accelerated so fast, but the proton ends up traveling at 99% of the speed of light and the mosquito travels at 0.000000003 % of the speed of light. (Assuming the mosquito weighs .005g and travels at a velocity of 1 m/s)
Yes, but is it a laden or un-laden mosquito?
It‚Äôs all a matter of weight ratios
